meanings.definition: To discount a negotiable instrument a second time.
meanings.sent1: I had to rediscount the check after I realized I made a mistake.
meanings.sent2: Banks sometimes rediscount loans to help customers in financial need.
meanings.sent3: The teacher asked the student to rediscount the math problem for practice.
meanings.sent4: She decided to rediscount her options before making a final decision.
meanings.sent5: The mechanic had to rediscount the repair cost after finding a cheaper solution.

meanings.definition: To discount a negotiable instrument for a second time.
meanings.sent1: After the error was discovered, they had to rediscount the bill.
meanings.sent2: The store agreed to rediscount the price for the loyal customer.
meanings.sent3: The chef had to rediscount the recipe to make it healthier.
meanings.sent4: He decided to rediscount his chances of winning the game.
meanings.sent5: The artist had to rediscount the painting to attract more buyers.

meanings.sent1: The rediscount of the bond helped the company save money.
meanings.sent2: She learned about the importance of rediscount in financial management.
meanings.sent3: The unexpected rediscount of the coupon made the customer happy.
meanings.sent4: The rediscount of the ticket allowed more people to attend the event.
meanings.sent5: His knowledge of rediscount made him a valuable asset to the team.
